Fair trials. Broken rules.

The phrase "prosecutorial misconduct" means when lawyers who work for the government break the rules to win a case. It’s like a referee changing the score to help their favorite team.

Prosecutors have a lot of power—they decide who gets charged with crimes and what evidence to show in court. But sometimes, they hide evidence that could help the defendant, or they pressure witnesses to lie. Other times, they make unfair arguments to the jury, like saying things that aren’t allowed.

One famous case involved a man named Michael Morton. Prosecutors hid a bloodstained bandana that could have proven he didn’t kill his wife. He spent 25 years in prison before DNA tests showed he was innocent.

Misconduct doesn’t always mean someone goes to jail unfairly. But when it happens, it can ruin lives. Courts have rules to stop this, but not everyone follows them.

Justice. Trust. Accountability.
